data.title: Which Nintendo home console had the worst twilight years (post SNES)?
data.meta_description: After the Super Nintendo, Nintendo's home consoles had a tendency to struggle with going out gracefully. Whether that be Nintendo shifting development...
data.text:
MagiCarbo

Bob-omb

Aug 2, 2024

#1

After the Super Nintendo, Nintendo's home consoles had a tendency to struggle with going out gracefully. Whether that be Nintendo shifting development resources to the next gen system very early, leaving the last few years pretty dry. The lack of substantial third party support that amplifies the problem. Or declining sales and user interest in these platforms compared to other consoles during their time. Nintendo's home gaming platforms have had pretty barren final years.

But, which one had the absolute driest twilight years?...

While the Nintendo 64 was notorious for its lengthy game droughts that seemed to get worse as they went on, the console still had some notable bangers in 2000, such as Perfect Dark, Kirby 64: The Crystal Shards, Banjo Tooie, and The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask. 2001 meanwhile had Paper Mario, Conker's Bad Fur Day and... uh... Dr. Mario 64? Yeah the N64 kind of faded out anti-climactically in 2001.

The Nintendo GameCube was at its lowest point in 2005. It's only real third party exclusive of the year, Resident Evil 4, was now only a timed exclusive (coming to PlayStation 2 later that Fall). Many big third party games that were comming to rival consoles, were now just skiping the GameCube, and Microsoft had kickstarted the next generation early with the launch of the Xbox 360. Meanwhile, besides some cult hits like Donkey Kong Jungle Beat, Fire Emblem Path of Radiance, and Super Mario Strikers, Nintendo didn't really have much noteworthy for its troubled square. The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess was once again delayed, now comming to the then codenamed Revolution, and other Nintendo games that year were pretty mid (Star Fox Assault and Geist being the most notable examples). The only Nintendo games that came out in 2006 for the GameCube were Chibi-Robo, And Baiten Kaitos Origins... Yup.

The Wii in 2011 had seen much of its core audience flee to rival platforms including Xbox 360 thanks to Kinect, and especially smartphones and tablets. And besides The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword and Kirby's Return to Dreamland, Nintendo offered pretty much nothing of interest to the remaining "core gamer" Wii owners. Especially frustraiting when there were games they could've released in North America. Operation Rainfall, the fabled fan-campain to preasure Nintendo of America to release three high quality Wii RPGs in the US. Xenoblade Chronicles, The Last Story, and Pandora's Tower. Thankfully 2012 saw the first two games release here, which also had Rhythm Heaven Fever and... That's basically it.

The Wii U was gasping for air in 2015. Some of Nintendo's worst games of all time headlined the Fall lineup with Mario Tennis Ultra Smash, Animal Crossing Amiibo Festival, and Devil's Third. Splatoon and Super Mario Maker finally showed the Wii U GamePad's potential, but by that point, it was too little, too late. Despite that, 2015 still had some solid games including Yoshi's Wooly World, Kirby and the Rainbow Curse, and Xenoblade Chronicles X. 2016 however... Well, you had Tokyo Mirage Sessions #FE... and Paper Mario Color Splash... and Star Fox Zero...

Fortunately, it seems like the Nintendo Switch is looking to break this curse thanks to inhereting Nintendo's handheld DNA. 2023 will go down as one of the Switch's greatest years. With games like Fire Emblem Engage, Pikmin 4, Advance Wars 1+2 ReBoot Camp, Metroid Prime Remastered, The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom, and Super Mario Bros. Wonder among others. And while the first half of 2024 was fairly heavy on the remake/remaster/DLC variety with games like Another Code Recollections, Splatoon 3 Side Order, Mario Vs. Donkey Kong, and Paper Mario: The Thousand Year Door, it's still preferable to the months of nothing that defined Nintendo consoles of the past, with Fall housing Emio The Smiling Man - Famicom Detective Club, Mario & Luigi Brothership, The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom, and more to come in 2025 headlined by the long-delayed Metroid Prime 4: Beyond.

PixelKnight

Observing the process

Pronouns

He/Him

To be fair, 2014 was the only year the Wii U actually had any relevance with Mario Kart 8, Bayonetta 2, Super Smash Bros. For Wii U, Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze. That was a really good year for Wii U, at least from a first party perspective.

#8

Late 2015/2016/early 2017 was like, comically bad for the WiiU. Everything of note was clearly getting saved for the Switch aside from BotW which was promised for WiiU, and Star Fox Zero which was so heavily designed around the gamepad it's stopped it from getting ported even now. Mario Tennis Ultra Smash was so clearly just shoved out the door in it's most basic functional form because they knew it could be used as a base for Aces.

A lot of the really neat games around that time were either 3DS exclusive or were later ported to 3DS because they needed it to be on something that was actually making money. For every other console I can name some big heavy hitters, but for the WiiU? Yeah, I've got nothing.

I mean in some ways, the Wii's final years were worse. At least with the Wii U, you had Splatoon and Mario Maker in 2015 as the last hurrah. What did the Wii have in 2011? A simple 2D Kirby game? A Zelda game with a very divided reception among fans? All the while Nintendo of America was keeping some potential heavy hitters hostage with the Rainfall games.

#20

Wii U is a weird one because there were some great games that came out in 2015, but 2016 was absolutely dire. Like worse than any of these other options by a significant margin.

Wii U 2016 had Pokken, Star Fox Zero, Tokyo Mirage Sessions, Paper Mario Color Splash and updates for Super Mario Maker and Splatoon. It's objectively a weak year but I'd still put it above something like Wii 2012 which was literally just Mario Party 9, Xenoblade localization and Kirby ports (most of which were already on VC).

Tuesday at 5:58 PM

#22

Wii, without a doubt.

It's twilight years shows how the blue ocean strategy nose dived and was short-lived in the long-run. Wii is the only top selling system of a generation to die first than it's undersellers competitors, something unprecedented in the gaming industry. This is a demostrative why staying a generation hardware-wise is a risky strategy despite having stellar frontloaded sales.

#24

Wii, without a doubt.

It's twilight years shows how the blue ocean strategy nose dived and was short-lived in the long-run.

Wii falling off the cliff didn't mean the Blue Ocean strategy didn't have any merit. Rather it was entirely self-inflicted by Nintendo refusing to release games in America.

Look at how well Nintendo's other Blue Ocean successes, particularly the Switch, have held up even after seven years.

RoyalGoldenFES

Octorok

Pronouns

He/him

Tuesday at 10:44 PM

#25

The Wii probably, especially in North America where several games that did release in other regions didn't get releases at all. The console's third-party support also pretty much dried up as Nintendo and partners' resources switched focus to the Wii U and 3DS, while every other major developer focused more on the HD twins. There were some games of note (Skyward Sword, Kirby's Return to Dream Land, Xenoblade), but the console basically got little to no support at all through all of 2012 outside of the Operation Rainfall trio in North America.

The Wii U's is right behind it, although it still had some notable releases in mid-late 2015 and 2016 (Yoshi's Woolly World, Xenoblade X in the West, TMS #FE, Zelda TPHD, Paper Mario) before ending with BOTW. This makes the Wii's probably worse though, since the Wii U was functionally dead by then while the Wii was extremely successful up through 2010.

Wednesday at 8:50 AM

#27

WiiU for sure. Mid 2015 to the release date of Switch were my "the dark age" of being a Nintendo fan. What made it worse that even the 3DS didn't get many games that caught my attention other than Majora's Mask 3D. It's the lowest point of Nintendo I've ever witnessed.

Although retrospectively, Wii's twilight years are also bad. But somehow it didn't feel as bad as WiiU for me.

Look at how well Nintendo's other Blue Ocean successes, particularly the Switch, have held up even after seven years.

Wednesday at 10:50 AM

#37

N64 in 2021 had few, but good games. Paper Mario was born. Dr Mario 64 was ok. There were also decent iterations in Pokemon Stadium 2 and Mario Party 3. Nintendo largely cut off support for that system pretty quickly.

Gamecube in 2006 was a lot more dire. It was Chibi Robo, Odama, Baiten Kaitos: Origins, and then Twilight Princess.

Wii in 2012 was saved heavily by Xenoblade Chronicles. Outside of that, it was largely just re-releases.

Wii-U in its last year has an edge over the other systems when it comes to quantity. Nintendo published 9 games in the last 12 months for the system. Most of them were forgettable like Star Fox: Zero, but there were gems like Paper Mario: Color Splash. Also, a GOTG candidate in Breath of the Wild released on the system. That has to count for something.

So my vote is for the Gamecube. That last year was really rough for the system. At least the other three can say that they had one franchise building moment in their last year.

Wednesday at 11:00 AM

#38

It's a hard question for me, simply case woo U had Botw, one of the best games.

GC had many moved to Wii but still a passable lineup and TP. Subjectively I would point to switch fully aware that it's only cause the last 2 years where not to my taste, but I would be objectively wrong.

Probably still Wii U or Wii?

Maybe I'm misremembering n64... But zoie and mm where strong entries

Wednesday at 11:03 AM

#39

Wii U has Splatoon so I'm gonna go with Wii. Ultimately I think it's a good thing that these systems' last years tend to be quiet though. It just reflects the fact that Nintendo plans their releases well and starts work for the new system in advance

JazzPotatoes

Koopa

Pronouns

He/Him

Wednesday at 1:16 PM

#40

I think there's always going to be a strong factor of however the years were when a console was at its peak, is going to colour how people view the twilight years.

You can make the argument that the Wii had fewer first party games in its twilight years than the Wii U, and technically you're not wrong. The difference is that the Wii had a solid four year period where it was absolutely crushing it, and Nintendo (and others) were putting out certifiable megabits. Someone could pick up a Wii in 2011, and even if there wasn't that much on the horizon, there was an absurd library and back catalogue of banging games to get into.

The Wii U, on the other hand, never felt like it got off the ground.

Wednesday at 2:02 PM

#41

been there for all the end of life gens. the post SNES ones were all pretty bad tbh until Switch, but they really did feel progressively worse each time

and the bleakness of 2016 Wii U was particularly palpable online

I think part of that had to do with how the hopes some fans had for a potential Wii follow-up console alleviated, somewhat, that console's end of life drought period, the same way hopes for the "Revolution" calmed disappointments with Gamecube's final years, or the idea that Nintendo would be embracing a disc based console helped provide some real hope for what would come after the N64

whereas most folks online in 2016 just seemed to have no belief left whatsoever in Nintendo to actually turn things around with a follow up to the Wii U

like people were talking about potential new Nintendo consoles then the same way they do future Xbox consoles today

and that's bleak bleak

Zeal543

Chain Chomp

Wednesday at 3:04 PM

#42

Wii or wiiu

If it wasn't for the xenoblade games, I don't think there's anything I'd care for. WiiU ended with BotW so I'll say wii was worse.

tuskoub

Piranha Plant

Pronouns

he/him

Wednesday at 4:28 PM

#43

Easily the Wii U, I don't think it's fair to just give it credit for the great titles we got from it in those last two years (Mario Maker, Splatoon, Xenoblade X), but even then, those all came in 2015, not 2016 (its actual last year). We bore witness to some of Nintendo's all-time worst games during that period that I don't think a few good titles can just counterbalance it. They should be taken as a whole, not just judged by their best or worst titles.

Wednesday at 7:06 PM

#44

Definitely the Wii or Wii U, though both kind of went out with a nice bang with the two next big Zelda games.

Just as OP said, Nintendo 64 went down swinging! The last 18 months had Banjo-Tooie, Majora’s Mask, Mario Party 3, Perfect Dark, Conker, Paper Mario. I think there’s a good argument to be had that it had the best twilight years for a console.

Gartooth

Universal Madness

Pronouns

He/him

Wednesday at 7:15 PM

#45

Wii was the worst by far

For Wii U they had games rolling out consistently in 2015 and the first half of 2016 even though some of those games are garbage like Mario Tennis Ultra Smash and Animal Crossing Amiibo Festival. Second half of 2016 was a bad drought with only Color Splash though.

Wii on the other hand was a barren wasteland in 2011 and 2012 if you were a Nintendo fan in North America in particular. The biggest new games drop was Skyward Sword and Return to Dreamland both in holiday 2011. Otherwise it was just empty, so empty in fact that a grass roots fan campaign in Operation Rainfall happened just so that we could get some games to play on the Wii. If Rainfall hadn't succeeded we would've had like nothing in 2012.

Last edited: Wednesday at 7:23 PM

ammonite

agent chieftain here

Pronouns

She/her

Wednesday at 7:25 PM

#46

The upside of how slow Nintendo used to be bringing games to Europe means our final years were sometimes slightly better stacked. Paper Mario & Banjo Tooie came out in Europe after the US & Japan already had the GameCube. The Oracles games and Pokémon Crystal both came out six months after the GBA. The GameCube only got three new non-Twilight Princess games (Chibi Robo, Mario Strikers and Odama) in the 13 months before the Wii in the US. Europe also got Mario Party 7, Battalion Wars, Fire Emblem, Pokémon XD and Mario Baseball!

This is the only circumstances where this can be considered a win.

Xbro

I think Wii U is winning because those years are still fresh in everyone's minds. It also doesn't help that the 3DS was in its twilight years at the same time. Looking at GC and Wii they seem worse off. But all of these systems had a Zelda game in there

The Wii U at least always had Breath of the Wild in the horizon for its last release and 2016 had something going on.
